title: Historical Note
creator: Gillespie Cemetary Association; Heath, Kathy; Ague, Linda; Lane County History Museum
description: Note added in 2002 by Kathy Heath (Gillespie Cemetary Association) to the Find a Grave page for William Lester "Bill" Gilham, explaining the prohibition against Black people owning property in Eugene prior to the 1960s and detailing racist violence against Tent City inhabitants in the 1940s. The purpose of the notice seems to be to laud the Gilhams for not participating in a campaign to force Black families out of their neighborhood, and it uses offensive language, suggesting that it may be a remediation of older materials on file in the records of the Gillespie Cemetary, where Gilham was buried in 1958. The notice was included in an email from Linda Ague to a correspondent seeking information about Gilham and was printed out and highlighted for inclusion in the Reynolds Family Collection at Lane County History Museum, presumably because of its reference to Leo and Pearl Washington and the demolition of Tent City.
subject: racism; prejudices; newspapers; zoning, exclusionary
publisher: Find a Grave; Lane County History Museum
source: Reynolds Family Collection, MS 510, Lane County History Museum; https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/6563412/william-lester-gilham

title: Changing Demographics: Difficult Times In Lane County
creator: Dole, Mary; Lane County Historical Society and Museum
description: Excerpt from the Changing Demographics exhibit catalog. Oregon not a welcoming place for people who were not white or protestant. laws have been enacted excluding residence in the state and ownership of land by people of color, and also making interracial marriage a criminal act. Oregon voted to exclude African-Americans from living in Oregon. Thus Oregon became the only state admitted to the Union with an exclusion law in its constitution (see paragraphs 4-7).
subject: local history materials; prejudices; racism; emmigration and immigration; zoning, exclusionary; advocacy group; Eugene, Or.
rightsholder: Lane County History Museum; City of Eugene
source: Changing Demographics: The People of Lane County, Lane Country History Museum

title: Changing Demographics: Introduction
creator: Dole, Mary; Lane County Historical Society and Museum
description: An introduction to an article discussing the goals of a Lane County History Museum exhibit that showcases Oregon's pioneer history and has expanded to discuss the history of ethnic and racial groups in Oregon history. This article mentions Oregon's journey to statehood, the origins of westerns settlers, as well as the experiences of Indigenous groups, Chinese railroad workers, African American and Black communities, and Latino agricultural workers. A black-and-white photo shown on first page titled Connie Mesquita Family, 1940. The second page is the same article in Spanish with racial and ethnic demographics from 1990, 2000, and 2007.
subject: local history materials; prejudices; emmigration and immigration; Oregon history; Chinese American history; railroad histroy; Black history; vaqueros; Latino American; North American Indigenous; immigration; pioneers; racism
rightsholder: Lane County History Museum; City of Eugene
source: Changing Demographics: The People of Lane County, Lane Country History Museum

title: Changing Demographics: Jewish Communities of Lane County
creator: Dole, Mary; Lane County Historical Society and Museum
description: This excerpt from the Changing Demographics exhibit catalog depicts Eugene's early Jewish community, which was comprised of a small number of families that emigrated from Germany. Prominent figures in the Jewish community included Sam Friendly and Goodman Bettman. The article discusses the perception among non-Jewish residents that Jewish-Americans have generally experienced acceptance in Eugene, and also notes incidents of discrimination and harassment that contradict this consensus.
subject: local history materials; prejudices; racism; emmigration and immigration; frontier and pioneer life; Oregon Trail; Jewish People
rightsholder: Lane County History Museum; City of Eugene
source: Changing Demographics: The People of Lane County, Lane Country History Museum

title: Changing Demographics: The Kalapuya Tribe
creator: Dole, Mary; Lane County Historical Society and Museum
description: Excerpt from the Changing Demographics exhibit catalog. Contains information regarding the history, reservation agreement and nomadic patterns of the Kalapuya people. Despite land being promised to their tribe, this agreement was slowly chipped away at which resulted in a significant loss of their tribal presence.
subject: local history materials; Kalapuya Indians; Native Americans; colonization; communicable disease; treaty

title: League of Women Voters of Eugene Report: "The Negro in Eugene"
creator: League of Women Voters of Eugene; Andrews, Gerrie; Baldinger, Ellen; Belser, Wilma; Donovan, Charlotte; Edwards, Maecel; Hansen, Vera; Janes, Teresa; Nicholson, Gail
description: A report produced by the League of Women Voters of Eugene's newly formed Minorities committee (comprised of white women) which attempts to articulate the most pressing problems facing Eugene's Black residents. The report details the conditions of Black neighborhoods, notes community attitudes toward Black residents, and examines Black residents' ability to access housing, employment, education, and social services.
subject: human rights advocacy; African Americans; anti-Black racism
rightsholder: Lane County History Museum; City of Eugene
source: MS 86, Lane County History Museum

title: EPA Links Pesticide to Cancer, May Suggest Restrictions Later
creator: Dodge, Steve
description: This column discusses how Creosote and Penta are used as a pesticide and to protect wood from rot. Two Eugene telephone pole companies use both of these substances to protect the poles in town. The EPA reviews the benefits and harms of Creosote and Penta to decide whether to ban its use.
subject: creosote; toxicity testing; hazardous wastes
source: Historic Oregon Newspapers via UO Libraries

title: Funding Crisis Poses A Threat to Home Care

It outlines a story of how economic pressures may be leading to a loss of in-home nursing services for elderly community members. The article highlights the experiences of Annie Mims, age 86, and her nurse, Gladys Krebs, age 68.

subject: racism; prejudices; newspapers; African American/Black communities; African American churches; religion; Reynolds family

title: Marking history - A memorial would recognize two homes’ role in the city’s past
creator: Baker, Mark
description: Willie Mims discusses his plan to fundraise to memorialize the homes at 330 & 336 High St. in honor of his parents, C.B. and Annie Mims, who purchased the properties in 1948. The memorial acknowledges the struggle and subsequent communities formed by Black people outside Eugene during a time when they were not allowed to live in city bounds.
subject: local history materials; land use; prejudices; local history materials; African American/Black communities; racism; civil rights movements; memorials; history
source: https://infoweb.newsbank.com/apps/news/document-view?p=WORLDNEWS&t=stp%3ANewspaper%21Newspaper/pubname%3AERGB%21Register-Guard%252C%2BThe%2B%2528Eugene%252C%2BOR%2529&sort=YMD_date%3AD&maxresults=20&f=advanced&val-base-0=willie%20mims&fld-base-0=alltext&bln-base-1=and&val-base-1=09/27/2015&fld-base-1=YMD_date&docref=news/1583005A26A73F98

title: A Mother to Many: Mattie Reynolds
creator: Wright, Jeff
description: A newspaper article announcing the death and honoring the life of Mattie Reynolds (1918-2010). The matriarch of one of Eugene's first African American families, Reynolds was a community activist and one of the first Black residents to seek elective office in Eugene in 1966. She was also the last living founder of the predominantly Black St. Mark's Christian Methodist Episcopal Church. The article outlines some of Reynolds's other important affiliations, as well as her cause of death. Also included is an image of Reynolds in front of the St. Mark's Church.
subject: racial equality; newspaper; African American churches; African American/Black communities; Black women; environmental racism; municipal government; death announcements; Reynolds family
source: http://special.registerguard.com/csp/cms/sites/web/updates/25234433-46/reynolds-mattie-eugene-family-black.csp

subject: land use; city planning; zoning; cities and towns--growth; municipal government

title: Cultural Demolition: What Was Lost When Eugene Razed Its First Black Neighborhood?
creator: Beckner, Chrisanne
description: MS Thesis submitted to Interdisciplinary Studies Program in Historic Preservation at University of Oregon. This thesis records the history and demolition of Eugene's first Black neighborhood, and examines the roles of race and class in this history. It then analyzes methods of historic preservation and public commemoration to make recommendations for a commemorative plan.

title: Butterflies In West Eugene
creator: City of Eugene; North American Butterfly Association
description: A scientific and taxonomic list of the North American Butterflies Occurring North of Mexico provided by The North American Butterfly Association. The list is split into eight categories: Papilonidae, Pieridae, Lycaenidae, Lycaenidae, Nymphalidae, Hesperidae, Hesperidae and Day-Flying Moths.
subject: Butterflies, Pieridae, Lycaenidae, Lycaenidae, Nymphalidae, Hesperidae, Hesperidae,
source: https://www.eugene-or.gov/DocumentCenter/View/56791/Butterflies-in-West-Eugene

title: Birds of West Eugene
creator: City of Eugene
description: A document that lists the different species of birds that inhabit the wetlands and forested areas of West Eugene. The list provides the birds common name, scientific name, and the time of year they can be seen in West Eugene.
subject: birds; birding sites; wetlands;
source: https://www.eugene-or.gov/DocumentCenter/View/56792/Birds-in-West-Eugene

title: Land and Water in West Eugene
creator: City of Eugene
description: The document describes the geology and geomorphology of the waterways in West Eugene. It studies the content of the local ground water and surface water. It notes the surrounding vegetation and the direction of flow of the rivers and creeks of West Eugene. Specifically Amazon Creek, Willow Creek and the A3 Channel. Identifies floodplains and wetland areas in West Eugene.
subject: land use – planning; wetland management
source: https://www.eugene-or.gov/DocumentCenter/View/56793/Lane-and-Water-in-West-Eugene

title: West Eugene Wetland Guide
creator: City of Eugene; Lane Council of Governments; Nature Conservancy; National Park Service; Lane County Audubon Society; Gleason, Barbara; Kerst, Cary; Benotsch, Matthew; Stutzman, Esther; Finney, Sarah
description: This poster combines photos and information from Eugene organizations to provide the public with information different areas within West Eugene's Wet Lands. Meadowlark Prairie is being restored to reflect and return the land to its historic terrain. Bertelsen Nature Park houses a wide variety of species and habitats. Tsal Luk-wah "River of Grass" is a wet prairie located in the center of the West Eugene Wetlands. This prairie was named to reflect its connection to the Kalapuyan people.
subject: wetland management; Kalapuya Indians; parks
source: https://www.eugene-or.gov/DocumentCenter/View/28159/West-Eugene-Wetlands-Guide

title: Dragonflies in West Eugene
creator: City of Eugene
description: A list of dragonfly and damselfly species that can be found in West Eugene. The West Eugene Wetlands, specifically Bertelsen Nature Park was the best place to observe dragonflies and damselflies in the Willamette Valley when the report was published.
subject: dragonflies; wetland management; wetland biodiversity
source: https://www.eugene-or.gov/DocumentCenter/View/56796/Dragonflies-in-West-Eugene

title: Reptiles, Amphibians and Mammals in West Eugene
creator: City of Eugene
description: A record of the verified reptiles, amphibians, and mammals that reside in West Eugene.
subject: reptiles;mammals;amphibians;animals
source: https://www.eugene-or.gov/DocumentCenter/View/56795/Reptiles-Amphibians-and-Mammals-in-West-Eugene

title: Historical Vegetation in West Eugene
creator: City of Eugene
description: Prior to the 1850s, Kalapuya Native Americans were located along the Willamette Valley and used wetland plants for many purposes. Their practices had created many historical wetland types. This article discusses the environmental changes the Willamette Valley and the wetlands of West Eugene went through during European settlement. Growing Eugene and the engineering of dams have since changed the wetland management.
subject: Kalapuya Indians; land use; wetland management; industrial development projects
source: https://www.eugene-or.gov/DocumentCenter/View/56794/Historical-Vegetation-in-West-Eugene

title: "I Too Am Eugene": Project Studies History and Contributions of Minority Citizens
creator: Mosley, Joe
description: Describes a summer youth program put on by Lane Community College and created by two Black residents of Eugene, Cheri Turpin and Mark Harris, who felt their children weren't being taught enough about Black history in school. This part of the program included a half-day tour of Eugene for Black middle and high school students that visited several important historical sites of Black history in Eugene, including Wiley Griffon's grave, the St. Mark Church (where they had a Q&A session with Mattie Reynolds), and the Mims family home. The program, named "I Too Am Eugene," also included offerings for Asian, Latinx, and Indigenous children.
subject: African American/Black communities; education; history; racism; newspapers
source: https://infoweb.newsbank.com/apps/news/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info%3Asid/infoweb.newsbank.com&svc_dat=WORLDNEWS&req_dat=0F4D0B17197442A2&rft_val_format=info%3Aofi/fmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Actx&rft_dat=document_id%3Anews%252F10D4EA6A45139368

title: First at Bat: The Legacy of the Eugene Larks
creator: Wolfe, Mike
description: Article about the Eugene Larks, the first professional baseball team to call Eugene, Oregon home. The Larks played at a stadium called Bethel Park. In 1952, the Larks ceased to exist, which resulted in the birth of the Eugene Emeralds in 1955. By 1968, Bethel Park was destroyed, and Civic Park was built.
subject: building; athletic fields; stadiums; minor league baseball; local history materials
source: https://eugenemagazine.com/community-pulse/first-at-bat/

title: Tent City Stakes Its Claim in History
creator: Maben, Scott
description: This article talks about Lane Community College's Black Student Union and its reenactment of Eugene's Tent City in honor of Black History Month. Students pitched a tent in Alton Baker Park to recall the era of Tent City in the 1940's, which was the only part of town Black residents were allowed to reside in until the area was bulldozed to allow for reconstruction of the Ferry Street bridge, forcing Tent City residents to relocate to parts of Glenwood and West Eugene. Mattie Reynolds of Reynolds family legacy is sourced as somebody who lived in Tent City and remembered what it was like to be there.
subject: zoning, exclusionary; African American History Month; prejudices; segregation; advocacy; housing; discrimination in housing; racism against Black people
source: https://infoweb.newsbank.com/apps/news/document-view?p=WORLDNEWS&docref=news/108502A9DDD73D18

title: Mother Reynolds' Day
creator: Freehan, Jim
description: St. Mark Christian Methodist Episcopal Church recognizes the contributions of 84-year-old Mattie Reynolds to both the church and the city of Eugene, Oregon. The article highlights her dedication and impact within the church community as well as her involvement in local politics. In 1966 Reynolds became the first Black candidate to run for public office in Lane County. She has also worked with the Congress for Racial Equality to challenge job and housing discrimination that she personally experienced.
subject: prejudices; segregation; communities--religious aspects--African American churches; local history materials; Reynolds family; zoning, exclusionary; racial relations; African American/Black communities; religion
source: https://infoweb.newsbank.com/apps/news/document-view?p=WORLDNEWS&docref=news/10D4EA7787AC0128

title: Lane County BIPOC Map and Location Details
creator: Lane County; City of Eugene; Lane County Historical Society
description: This work showcases two maps, comprised by Lane County Officials, identifying locations throughout the area of significance or history regarding Black, Indigenous, and People of Color's (BIPOC) communities. The two maps mostly cover the Eugene-Springfield Metro Area and the Ferry Street Bridge area in Eugene, Oregon. These maps indicate where either Community Efforts, Government Action, Immersion Schools, Across the Bridge Communities, or Organized Racism took place in these regions regarding the BIPOC communities of Lane County. The images are originally taken from an interactive website, where the specific location name pops up that corresponds with the descriptions. In this document, below the maps are detailed descriptions associated with each identified location, including the label, address, and other source materials which support the classification. Here is the interactive website: https://public.tableau.com/app/profile/lane.county/viz/LaneCountyBIPOCTimelineMap/IntroPage
subject: Black/African American communities; indigenous communities; map collections; community organization; government; Study and teaching--Immersion method; racism; racial justice; history
source: https://p1cdn4static.civiclive.com/UserFiles/Servers/Server_3585797/File/Government/Advisory%20Boards%20and%20Commissions/Equity%20and%20Access%20Advisory%20Board/Lane%20County%20BIPOC%20Map%20&%20Location%20Detail.pdf

title: Manufacturing Cluster Report

description: This report provides an analysis of current manufacturing practices in Eugene, places them in the broader context of international manufacturing trends, and provides suggestions for moving forward and developing the manufacturing sector in the Eugene-Springfield area.

title: Eugene Councilors Planning Sessions on Expanding Authority over Polluters
creator: Duvernay, Adam
description: Article reports that Eugene City Council will re-evaluate industrial pollution protection policies in response to the finding that J.H. Baxter wood treatment plant has released carcinogenic chemicals in West Eugene. The Council is considering possible zoning changes and may require polluters to publish risk mitigation bonds. Other stakeholders mentioned in the article include the Oregon Department of Environmental Quality, the Lane Regional Air Protection Agency, and the nonprofit Beyond Toxics.
subject: environmental protection; carcinogens; industrial pollution; city council; zoning
source: https://infoweb.newsbank.com/apps/news/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info%3Asid/infoweb.newsbank.com&svc_dat=WORLDNEWS&req_dat=0F4D0B17197442A2&rft_val_format=info%3Aofi/fmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Actx&rft_dat=document_id%3Anews%252F1891E49982E52E30
